sentences: Louis Joseph Ferdinand Herold (28 January 1791 – 19 January 1833), better known as Ferdinand Hérold (pronounced [fɛʁdinɑ̃ eʁɔld]), was a French composer.
He is best known today for the ballet La Fille mal gardée and the overture to the opera Zampa.
Born in Paris to a musical family, Hérold trained at the Paris Conservatoire and won France's premier musical prize, the Prix de Rome in 1812.

Some of them particularly in his early days, were hampered by poor librettos, but later he had more successes than failures, and his last two operas, Zampa (1831) and Le Pré aux clercs (The Clerk's Meadow, 1832) were immensely popular, and remained in the repertory in France and elsewhere for decades after his early death from tuberculosis in 1833.

sentences: The composer's father, François-Joseph Herold (1755–1802) was the son of an organist in Seltz.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: François-Joseph studied music with C. P. E. Bach in Hamburg and moved to Paris in about 1780, where he worked as a composer, pianist and teacher.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: In 1790 he married Jeanne-Gabrielle Pascal.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: Their only child, Louis Joseph Ferdinand Herold, later widely known as Ferdinand Hérold, was born in what is now the rue Herold in the 1st arrondissement on 28 January 1791.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: Their only child, Louis Joseph Ferdinand Herold, later widely known as Ferdinand Hérold, was born in what is now the rue Herold in the 1st arrondissement on 28 January 1791.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: François-Joseph did not intend his son to follow him into the musical profession, but his death, from tuberculosis, in 1802 left Hérold free to do so.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: In 1806, when he was nearly 16, he entered the Paris Conservatoire, where he studied piano with Adam, harmony with Charles-Simon Catel and violin with Rodolphe Kreutzer.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: In 1810 he won the conservatoire's first prize for piano, playing one of his own compositions.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: In 1811 he was admitted to the composition class of Étienne Méhul, who esteemed his talents greatly, saw him as his successor, and became a much-loved father-figure to him.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: During 1812 works by Hérold were performed publicly for the first time.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: They included a piano concerto given on 6 April at the Théâtre Italien with the composer as soloist.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: In October 1812 Hérold was awarded France's premier musical prize, the Prix de Rome, which he won with a cantata, La Duchesse de la Vallière.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: The prize carried with it liberally subsidised residence and tuition at the Villa Medici, the French Academy in Rome, where Hérold went in 1813.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: Like his father, Hérold suffered from tuberculosis, and the climate of Rome did not suit him; he moved south to Naples in 1815.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: While in Naples, Hérold was commissioned in 1814 to write his first opera, La gioventù di Enrico quinto (The Boyhood of Henry V), to a libretto from Alexandre Pineux-Duval's play La jeunesse de Henry V about Prince Hal of England.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: It was premiered in January 1815 at the Teatro del Fondo before Murat's court, with Manuel García in the title role.
section: == Life and career == | === Background and early years ===

sentences: Hérold arrived back in Paris in August 1815, where he took the post of maestro al cembalo (deputy conductor and répétiteur) at the Théâtre Italien.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: In 1816 the composer François-Adrien Boieldieu invited him to collaborate on a new opera Charles de France, to which Hérold contributed the second act.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: In the same year he composed the opera Les Rosières, dedicated to Méhul, produced successfully at the Opéra-Comique.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: He had another success with La Clochette (The Bell, 1817), based on the story of Aladdin and his lamp; it ran well in Paris and was seen in Vienna (with additional numbers by Franz Schubert)
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: After these, he had difficulty finding adequate librettos, and suffered four failures in a row between 1818 and 1821, following which he gave up composing operas for more than two years.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: After these, he had difficulty finding adequate librettos, and suffered four failures in a row between 1818 and 1821, following which he gave up composing operas for more than two years.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: In 1821 the director of the Théâtre Italien asked Hérold to go to Italy to find new works and recruit new singers.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: He recruited singers including Giuditta Pasta, Filippo Galli for his Parisian employer.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: During 1823 Hérold had another opera produced, Le Muletier; despite an unimpressive libretto the music was well received.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: A one-act piece for the Paris Opéra, L'Asthénie, had a moderate run but was not well reviewed, and it was not until 1826 that he had another success, with Marie at the Opéra-Comique.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: In November 1826 Hérold gave up his post at the Théâtre Italien and became premier chef de chant (senior voice coach) at the Opéra, working on major works in the grand opéra genre such as Le Siège de Corinthe, Guillaume Tell, and Robert le diable.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to Paris ===

sentences: His position as chef de chant meant that he was barred from having his own operas performed at the Opéra, and his principal commissions there over the next three years were for ballet music: Astolphe et Jaconde (1827), La Somnambule  (The Sleepwalker) (1827), La Fille mal gardée  (1828) Lydie (1828), La Belle au bois dormant (The Sleeping Beauty) (1829) and La Noce de village (Village Wedding) (1830).

sentences: Final years =
Betzwieser writes that the composer's last three years were dominated by the writing of "his two masterpieces": Zampa (1831) and Le Pré aux clercs (1832).
Betzwieser writes that the composer's last three years were dominated by the writing of "his two masterpieces": Zampa (1831) and Le Pré aux clercs (1832).
Betzwieser writes that the composer's last three years were dominated by the writing of "his two masterpieces": Zampa (1831) and Le Pré aux clercs (1832).

The work had a tentative start because of a financial crisis at Opéra-Comique and the defection of the company's leading tenor, but it quickly became one of the most popular opéras comiques of the 19th century, in France and elsewhere, being staged in the US and Britain in 1833.

The work had a tentative start because of a financial crisis at Opéra-Comique and the defection of the company's leading tenor, but it quickly became one of the most popular opéras comiques of the 19th century, in France and elsewhere, being staged in the US and Britain in 1833.
During this period Hérold finished Le Pré aux clercs, to a libretto by Eugène de Planard based on Prosper Mérimée's historical novel Les Chroniques du temps de Charles IX (1829).
Betzwieser writes that it aroused wild enthusiasm at its premiere on 15 December 1832.
By the time of the first performance of Le Pré aux clercs in December 1832 the composer's tubercular condition had grown worse.
Five weeks after the premiere he died, at the age of 42, at his house in Paris, and was buried at Père Lachaise Cemetery.
His friend Fromental Halévy completed the score, and it was performed three months after Hérold's death.

sentences: By the end of the 19th century Le Pré aux clercs had been performed more than 1,500 times in Paris.

The musicologist Gustav Chouqet wrote in 1904 that Hérold's early symphonic, choral and chamber works show that the composer could have excelled in concert works had he continued in that type of composition, but the stage "possesses an irresistible attraction for a man gifted with ardent imagination and capacity for expressing emotion", leading Hérold to opera and the ballet.
Until Hérold's day the role of the composer was not a prestigious one in the world of ballet.

Although Hérold's name is associated in the public mind with the music for La Fille mal gardée, the score he wrote for the Opéra in 1828 differs substantially from that played in modern productions of the ballet.

Later productions have added music by Peter Ludwig Hertel, and the most famous number in the piece, the clog dance, is a modern invention, based on one of Hertel's tunes, by John Lanchbery, who revised the whole score in 1959 for Frederick Ashton's production.
In a 1904 survey of Hérold's work, Chouqet praised La Clochette for its abundance of new and fresh ideas, its stagecraft and original instrumentation.

He added that although its immediate successors showed the composer's industry and fertility, operas like Le premier venu (1818), Les Troqueurs (1819), L' Amour platonique (1819), and L'Auteur mort et vivant (1820) had "librettos that were neither interesting nor adapted for music" .

He added that although its immediate successors showed the composer's industry and fertility, operas like Le premier venu (1818), Les Troqueurs (1819), L' Amour platonique (1819), and L'Auteur mort et vivant (1820) had "librettos that were neither interesting nor adapted for music" .

He added that although its immediate successors showed the composer's industry and fertility, operas like Le premier venu (1818), Les Troqueurs (1819), L' Amour platonique (1819), and L'Auteur mort et vivant (1820) had "librettos that were neither interesting nor adapted for music" .

He added that although its immediate successors showed the composer's industry and fertility, operas like Le premier venu (1818), Les Troqueurs (1819), L' Amour platonique (1819), and L'Auteur mort et vivant (1820) had "librettos that were neither interesting nor adapted for music" .
Le Muletier (1823), however, is "full of life and colour, and assured his reputation".

Chouqet adds that after the success of the lively Le Muletier it is puzzling that a man of Hérold's literary tastes and culture should have chosen to set dramas "so tame and uninteresting as L'asthenie (1823), and Le Lapin blanc (1825)": he concludes that Hérold's urge to compose led him to accept any libretto offered to him.

Chouqet adds that after the success of the lively Le Muletier it is puzzling that a man of Hérold's literary tastes and culture should have chosen to set dramas "so tame and uninteresting as L'asthenie (1823), and Le Lapin blanc (1825)": he concludes that Hérold's urge to compose led him to accept any libretto offered to him.
By the time of the comedy Marie (1826) Hérold was incorporating elements of both Rossini's and Beethoven's musical language.

But Betzwieser observes that Zampa's Romantic features made it highly successful outside France, and writing in Grove's Dictionary of Music and Musicians the British critic Elizabeth Forbes commented in 1992, "All the music is perfectly suited to its subject, while the portions devoted to Zampa and the statue are highly dramatic as well as melodious".

In a 2016 analysis of the score, Gérard Condé writes, "Though doubtless derivative in certain respects, the score of Le Pré aux clercs went on to serve as a recipe book for the next half-century: Lecocq, Offenbach, Varney, Audran and even Bizet consulted it with profit, each to his own ends".
In the overture Hérold does not use themes from the opera, but ranges from an opening fugue to a quick march.

Wagner and Smetana both knew the opera well, and in another 2016 analysis, Damien Colas writes that echoes of Le Pré aux clercs may be found in the former's Das Liebesverbot (1836) and the latter's The Bartered Bride (1866).
